initial_story: My observation is there exists unequal share of State monies with its residents, before all the Urban residents get defensive please hear me out. Presently no one except Corporations pay State income taxes. No individual pays state taxes. I noticed state funded bicycle paths, road maintenance, defunct Docks, powerful politicians pet projects such as office buildings, state troopers etc, etc. all these fundings and more are not necessary within City limits, I was amazed at how much our state provides city functions in the bigger cities thus growing the state budget, I saw on tv last night how adg&g was showing the little ones how to ice fish, couldn't the parents do that? yes I pay property taxes. But I will guarantee you once our City folk get the full bill with out the State monies we will not be as wasteful, on the office building...rent what space you need and help the office rental marked. In my business I just retired from,I would ask my managers, "how do you stop spending money"?
stories: My reflection is there's an imbalance in community resources, before all the suburbanites get reactive, please listen. Currently, only Non-Profits contribute to local taxes. No individual pays local taxes. I've noticed city-funded parks, street repairs, defunct community centers, influential community leaders' pet projects such as event spaces, police officers, etc., etc. all these funding and more are not necessary within neighborhood limits, I was astonished at how much our city provides neighborhood functions in the smaller towns thus expanding the city budget, I saw on TV last night how a local teacher was showing the kids how to plant a garden, couldn't the parents do that? yes I pay property taxes. But I'll guarantee you once our suburban residents get the full bill without the city monies we will not be as extravagant, on the event space...rent what space you need and help the event rental market. In my neighborhood, I just moved from, I would ask my neighbors, "how do you save money"?

As I gaze at my reflection, I'm struck by the disparity in resources between our town's bustling center and its quiet outskirts. Before the suburbanites get riled up, let's take a moment to listen. The harsh reality is that Non-Profits are the sole contributors to local taxes, while individuals are exempt. It's astonishing to see how city-funded amenities, such as community centers, event spaces, and even police officers, are scattered throughout the neighborhood, straining the city's budget. I recall a recent TV program where a local teacher was teaching kids how to plant a garden. Couldn't parents take on this responsibility instead? I pay property taxes, but I'm confident that once our suburban residents bear the full weight of the bill without city subsidies, we'll be more frugal. Take the event space, for instance – rent what you need and support the local rental market. In my former neighborhood, I'd ask my neighbors, "How do you save money?" and we'd brainstorm ways to cut costs together.

As I stroll through the city's vibrant market, I'm struck by the contrast between the bustling stalls and the neglected alleys. Before the vendors get defensive, let's examine the economic divide. It's staggering to see how small businesses are forced to compete with government-subsidized corporations, while independent entrepreneurs struggle to stay afloat. I recall a recent visit to a local art studio where a community of artists shared resources and expertise. Couldn't we replicate this model, fostering collaboration and innovation instead of relying on handouts? I pay taxes, but I'm convinced that once our small business owners bear the full weight of the market without government support, we'll be more innovative. Take the public transportation system, for instance – invest in efficient routes and support local startups. In my former community, I'd ask my fellow entrepreneurs, "How do you adapt to change?" and we'd brainstorm ways to pivot together.

It's striking to see how this collective effort not only provides fresh produce but also fosters a sense of belonging. I recall a visit to a local woodworking co-op, where members shared tools and expertise, creating beautiful pieces that reflected their unique stories. Couldn't we replicate this model, nurturing community-driven initiatives instead of relying on top-down initiatives? I pay rent, but I'm convinced that once our local entrepreneurs are empowered to take ownership of their projects, we'll see a surge in creativity. Take the town's revitalized waterfront, for example – invest in public art installations and support local startups. In my former neighborhood, I'd ask my fellow residents, "How do you revitalize a space?" and we'd collectively brainstorm ways to reimagine and restore.

It's astonishing to see how this living legacy not only preserves the forest's history but also forges a sense of harmony. I recall a visit to a local weaver, where the artisan shared their life's passion, infusing each woven thread with the tales of their own. Couldn't we mirror this model, cultivating nature-driven cultural initiatives instead of chasing fleeting novelty? I notice, but I'm certain that once our wilderness wanderers are empowered to craft their own chronicles, we'll see a canopy of legends. Take the forest's revitalized ancient rituals, for instance – host impromptu forest performances and support local storytellers. In my childhood clearing, I'd ask my fellow wanderers, "What's your favorite myth?" and we'd collectively reimagine the legend to revitalize the heart of our forest.
